source.g: Use the Learning journal to record and save your answers to Practice Point questions.

source.g: By the end of this module you will:

source.g: Some of the clients you counsel and prescribe contraception to, may be vulnerable to experiencing intimate partner violence. It is important that you recognise, support and refer them to relevant services when appropriate and available.

source.g: Health workers are in an ideal position to identify clients who experience violence and to attend to their physical health needs as well as provide care and support.

source.g: IPV is defined as a behaviour by an intimate partner that causes physical, sexual or psychological harm, including acts of physical aggression, sexual coercion, psychological abuse and controlling behaviours.

source.g: Clients experiencing violence have special health needs, many of them sexual and reproductive health needs.

source.g: Which of these statements about sexually transmitted infections (STIs) should the pharmacist say to Adaora?

source.g: STIs are caused by bacteria, parasites and viruses that spread through sexual contact.

source.g: Men are more at risk of becoming infected with STIs than women.

source.bpt: <Style FontFamily="Roboto" />

source.g: Some STIs may not show any symptoms, and you should encourage Adaora to get tested regularly even if she does not have any symptoms or know if she has been exposed to an infected partner. Regular testing can help detect and treat STIs early and reduce the risk of transmission.

source.g: of condoms provides protection against both STIs and HIV. In addition to preventing these infections, condoms are the only contraceptive method that offers dual protection against pregnancy and STIs.

source.g: Some people engage in sexual practices that differ from the societal norm or are less commonly discussed. To provide these groups with effective protection against STIs you need to acknowledge and understand these sexual practices.

source.g: of condoms provides protection against both STIs and HIV. In addition to preventing these infections, condoms are the only contraceptive method that offers dual protection against pregnancy and STIs.

source.g: Women are at a higher risk of contracting STIs than men due to biological factors. The cervix and vagina provide a larger area of exposure, which can lead to small tears and an easier pathway for infection.

source.g: STIs are caused by bacteria, parasites, and viruses that are present in body fluids like semen, vaginal secretions, blood, skin around genitals, mouth, throat, and rectum.
source.ph: <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="19.5" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" DefaultTabStop="64" ListLevel="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"><ListStyle ListType="Bullet" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Start="0" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"><BulletPicture Size="0x0" /></ListStyle></Style>

source.g: STIs spread through sexual contact between an infected person and an uninfected person. The risk of transmission increases with the number of sexual partners.

source.g: Many clients who experience violence may present to healthcare facilities but may not disclose they are victims. Pharmacists play a crucial role in addressing intimate partner violence. They should ask the right questions, identify signs, offer support, and make appropriate referrals. Simply identifying signs and providing painkillers is not enough; listening, providing ongoing support, and information are also essential.

source.g: It can be difficult to ask a client about this topic but if you suspect intimate partner violence (IPV) you should always ask about it. Here are some examples of questions to begin the conversation.

trans-unit.source: How to ask clients about IPV

source.g: Additionally, you should pay attention to any injuries, non-verbal cues or behaviour that might suggest the person is a victim of intimate partner violence.

source.ph: <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Center" DefaultTabStop="64" ListLevel="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"><ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="0" Color="#000000" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"><BulletPicture Size="0x0" /></ListStyle></Style>

source.g: Has your husband (or partner) or someone else at home ever threatened to hurt you or physically harm you in some way?

source.g: I ask all my clients these questions to make sure they are safe.

source.g: Many people experience problems with their partner or someone else they live with, this can be very harmful to those involved.

source.g: Imagine if Mathilde had not said anything about a difficult time in her relationship. The pharmacist has no reason to suspect violence. Should the pharmacist ask her about this?

source.g: To help Mathilde feel comfortable, listen to Mathilde's concerns and put her at the centre of the conversation. This will make her feel comfortable and encourage her to speak openly. Let her know that the pharmacists will provide assistance in seeking support. Remember, IPV is not normal and must be handled with sensitivity and care.

source.g: To help Mathilde feel comfortable, listen to Mathilde's concerns and put her at the centre of the conversation. This will make her feel comfortable and encourage her to speak openly. Let her know that the pharmacists will provide assistance in seeking support. Remember, IPV is not normal and must be handled with sensitivity and care.

source.g: reflect where to refer clients at risk of sexually transmitted infections or intimate partner violence in own setting.

trans-unit.source: Here are some useful links and documents:
Indicators for an Eating Disorder Assessment
Risk Factors for Developing an Eating Disorder
Who to Screen for an Eating Disorder
Signs and Symptoms of Semi Starvation

4.1 Take a moment to reflect on what you have learned: How to ask clients about STIs and IPV How and where to refer clients for specialist services for STI or IPV in your area Think about how you can apply what you have learned into your practice and submit.
